oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Improved Ruminent Feed Efficiency with Rumensin
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Potter, E. L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: diet
ruminant feed
roughage
rumen fermentation
carbohydrates
energy losses
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ruminants are less efficient in converting non-roughage feedstuffs to meat than are monogastric animals. Part of the reason for this reduced efficiency is the significant loss of energy which results when the rumen microorganism ferment the feedstuffs. As a result of rumen fermentation, volatile fatty acids, microbial protein and gases are produced. The primary volatile fatty acids (VFA's) are acetic acid, propionic acid and butyric acid. All can be used by the ruminant for energy. However, the gases produced by fermentation, namely COâ‚‚ and methane, cannot be used by the animal and thus represent losses of energy. A more thorough examination of the biochemical pathways through which carbohydrates are fermented in the rumen will demonstrate how the fermentation might be theoretically shifted to reduce energy losses.
